title: Data-visual disproportion
description: This flaw occurs when the visual representation of data elements, such as bars in a bar chart or bubbles in a bubble chart, does not accurately reflect the underlying data values.

title: 3D effect
description: The existence of perspective can can distort the perception of data and make it challenging to accurately gauge the values represented in the visualization.

title: Truncated axis
description: When an axis in a visualization is truncated, the shape of the visualization can be distorted and users may not realize that the full extent of the data is not being shown.

title: Mathematical error
description: Numbers that do not make sense mathematically. For instance, it may manifest as percentages in a pie chart that do not collectively add up to 100%.

title: Dual encoding
description: This flaw uses multiple channels (e.g., both width and height) to represent the same data variable, thus exaggerating the visuals.

title: Pop-out effect on data marks
description: When certain elements within a visualization are made to stand out or pop out visually, their sizes will be exaggerated.

title: Conflating area with radius
description: When data is incorrectly encoded to the radius, it leads to a significant distortion in the visual representation (becasue s = 閿 閼 r^2).

title: Wrong label placement
description: Placing labels or data points in incorrect locations, such as labeling Canada within the territory of the United States.

title: Inverted axis
description: Inverting the direction of an axis (e.g., presenting time from right to left) can cause misinterpretation, especially if users are not aware of the inversion.

title: Legend-vis inconsistency
description: The information in the legend (e.g., color-coding) does not match the data representation in the visualization.

title: Misleading annotation
description: Incorrect annotations in a data visualization can lead users to draw incorrect conclusions about the data being presented.

title: Reasoning error
description: A data visualization leads users to draw conclusions that are not supported by the data.

title: Visualization-text disjunction
description: The textual descriptions and the visual elements in a visualization are detached. This can confuse users and hinder comprehension.

title: Typo / grammatical error
description: Mistakes in spelling or grammar within the visualization can detract from its professionalism and accuracy.

title: Visualization itself as embellishment
description: A data visualization is incorporated into a presentation or report but does not actually encode any meaningful data.

title: Invasion of figurative semantics
description: For example, using a map icon filled from left to right to represent bike usage in the US may convey the idea that bike usage is geographically restricted to the eastern part of the country.

title: Mixed use of channels
description: Ambiguity arises when multiple visual channels or chart types (e.g., pie chart, rose chart) are used inconsistently or confusingly within a single visualization.

title: Unclear symbols
description: The use of unclear or non-standard symbols (e.g., arrows) within a visualization can lead to ambiguity. Users may struggle to decipher the meaning of these symbols.

title: Unclear proxy for comparison
description: A data visualization lacks a clear and consistent proxy or baseline for comparison. For example, it is difficult to know where the bar should end (front of the car, or back of the car).

title: Illusion of inclusion/intersection/union
description: This flaw creates visual representations as if there is an inclusion, intersection, or union relashionship between data elements.

title: Ghost element
description: Elements in a data visualization that are left totally unexplained and do not represent any meaningful data.

title: Highlighting that resembles data elements
description: Highlighting specific elements in a way that makes them appear as though they are part of the data set can introduce ambiguity.

title: Misuse of part-to-whole relationship
description: This flaw occurs when the categories in a visualization designed to show proportion (e.g., pie chart) does not have a part-to-whole relationship.

title: Failure to show uncertainty
description: When uncertainty or variation in data is not adequately represented in a visualization, it can lead to an incomplete understanding of the data.

title: Continuous encoding for categorical data
description: Using continuous encoding techniques, such as color gradients or line connection, for categorical data.

title: Misuse of periodicity
description: This flaw happens often in periodic tables. For example, cats do not naturally exhibit the periodic properties that a periodic table is designed to represent.

title: Failure to display infinite/null values
description: Neglecting to represent zero values, infinite values, or null data points in a visualization.

title: Categorical encoding for continuous data
description: Representing data that varies continuously using discrete categories.

title: Misuse of cumulative relationship
description: Incorrectly combining data elements that do not logically add up or relate to one another.

title: Misuse of logical relationship
description: This design flaw arises when the visual representation suggests a logic that contradicts/incompatible with the actual logical relationship between data elements.

title: Failure to display ordinal data
description: Failure to display ordinal data happens when ordinal data (e.g., time, ranking) is not appropriately ordered.

title: Misuse of sequence
description: Presenting data in a sequential order that does not align with their inherent order or significance.

title: Misuse of hierarchy
description: Organizing non-hierachical data elements hierarchically.

title: Multiple scales
description: When different parts of the data are represented on disparate scales, it becomes challenging for users to make equitable comparisons.

title: Misaligned comparison
description: Data marks are not properly arranged or positioned in a coordinated manner.

title: Uneven data grouping
description: Uneven data grouping involves categorizing or grouping data elements in a way that unfairly favors one category over another. This can result in biased perceptions of the data.

title: Uneven axis interval
description: This inconsistency in scaling can disproportionately emphasize or diminish certain data points, leading to skewed interpretations of the data.

title: Comparing apples with oranges
description: The categories or data elements being compared are fundamentally dissimilar or unrelated.

title: Overlapping data marks
description: When data points overlap to a significant extent, they can obscure each other, making it difficult for users to distinguish individual data points and patterns within the visualization.

title: Text rotation
description: Text rotation may require users to strain or reorient themselves to read the content, which can hinder the clarity of the visualization.

title: Small size
description: Using excessively small text or data marks can reduce readability, especially when users struggle to discern details or labels due to their diminutive size.

title: Cluttered label lines
description: When label lines intersect or cluster densely around data points, it creates clutter, making it challenging for users to identify the relationships between labels and data.

title: Stylized effect on data marks
description: The excessive use of stylized effects like shadows or heavy gradients on data marks can make data itself difficult to read.

title: Indistinguishable colors/textures
description: When colors or textures used to represent different data categories or elements are too similar, users may have difficulty distinguishing between categories or interpreting the data.

title: Low foreground-background contrast
description: A lack of contrast between the foreground and the background can result in poor visibility and hinder the user's ability to extract information from the visualization.

title: Obscuring data with embellishment
description: Excessive use of decorative elements or embellishments that cover or overshadow the actual data can obscure key information and impede readability.

title: Colorblind unfriendliness
description: This oversight may cause colorblind individuals to misinterpret or miss crucial information.

title: Exceeding the canvas
description: Data elements or labels extending beyond the boundaries of the visualization canvas make users lose access to critical data points or context.

title: Glitch
description: Technical glitches or rendering issues in the visualization can severely impact readability.

title: Irregular segmentation/shaping
description: Irregular divisions or boundaries can make it challenging for users to discern patterns or draw meaningful comparisons within the data.

title: Inconsistent visual encodings
description: Inconsistency in how data is visually encoded (e.g., different colors for the same category, different categories with the same color) can lead to confusion and reduced efficiency.

title: Rainbow colormap
description: The use of rainbow colormaps can be inefficient, as the color transitions lack clear meaning and may not align with the data's underlying patterns.

title: Dual axes
description: Incorporating dual axes in a visualization complicates the interpretation of relationships between data points and requires users to mentally bridge the gap between different axes.

title: Unstructured layout
description: An unstructured or cluttered layout can impede efficiency by overwhelming users with information or making it challenging to locate and focus on relevant data points.

title: Violating the gestalt laws
description: Violating the principles of Gestalt psychology, such as proximity, similarity, and closure, can hinder efficiency.

title: Multiple channels for the same data type
description: Assigning multiple visual channels (e.g., color, size, shape) to represent the same data type can introduce redundancy and decrease efficiency.

title: overuse of categories/colors
description: Overcomplexity can occur when a data visualization attempts to represent an excessive number of categories or data points using a large palette of colors.

title: Meaningless/confounding encoding
description: When visual encoding choices lack clear meaning or introduce confusion, users may struggle to interpret the symbolism or mapping used to represent the data.

title: overuse of visual channels
description: Excessive use of channels can overwhelm users, making it challenging to identify which visual cues are the most important for understanding the data.

title: High information density
description: High information density occurs when a data visualization tries to pack a significant amount of data into a small space.

title: Single-value visualization
description: Visualizing a single value can result in unnecessary complexity as more straightforward representations could convey the information more efficiently and effectively.

title: Large number of units
description: Displaying a large number of individual data units without appropriate aggregation or summarization can overwhelm users and decrease efficiency.

title: Lack of labels
description: Without labels, users may struggle to understand what each data point represents, making it challenging to derive meaningful insights.

title: Lack of scales
description: When a data visualization omits scales on its axes or does not provide clear units of measurement, it can lead to Oversimplification.

title: Lack of legends
description: when a visualization lacks a legend to explain the meaning of colors, symbols, or other visual encodings, users become puzzled about how to interpret the visualization.

title: Lack of explanation for metrics
description: Failing to provide explanations or descriptions for the metrics or data sources used in a visualization can result in Oversimplification.

title: Label that lacks callout
description: When labels are incorporated but lack appropriate callout or emphasis, they are disconnected to the corresponding data points.

title: Semantically mismatch
description: Semantically mismatch refers to the use of visual elements or metaphors that do not align with the data's semantics.

title: Stretched imagery
description: Figurative elements or visual representations within a visualization are unnaturally elongated or distorted to accommodate specific data points.

title: Breaking convention
description: Abnormality in data visualization can arise when social conventions and norms (e.g., a clock should start at 12) are deliberately disregarded.

title: Cut-off imagery
description: Figurative elements or visual representations within a visualization are incompletely depicted or abruptly truncated, creating an awkward or jarring visual effect.

title: Unconventional analogy of data scales
description: Abnormality can occur when data scales are analogized in unusual or misleading ways.

title: Informal visualization for humor
description: Sometimes, a data visualization are created informally for humorous or satirical purposes. However, users may expect it to be serious and accurate.

title: Disturbing pattern/imagery
description: This design flaw in data visualization occurs when the imagery or patterns used in the visualization are disturbing, violent, or offensive.

title: Strong rhetoric
description: When a data visualization employs strong, biased, or emotionally charged visual language, it can be seen as aggressive.

title: Arrogant wording
description: The use of arrogant or condescending textual expression can come across as aggressive. This may include a tone that belittles or dismisses differing viewpoints or data interpretations.
